subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Other Languages
msgSnippet: ... The spelling rules for French are about as complicated as those for English, but there are only a handful of words that obey no rules at all, whereas
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> I'm curious about French. The problem with English spelling arises
> largely because of the heterogeneous sources of vocabulary (French
> being a major culprit, of course). French spelling is clearly not
> representative of current pronunciation, but the internal consistency
> of the orthography is much higher than in English. I just discussed
> this with a French coworker over lunch, and she said she rarely has to
> look words up in a dictionary when writing in French.

The spelling rules for French are about as complicated as those for
English, but there are only a handful of words that obey no rules at all,
whereas English is full of those. (The only ones that come to mind are
the useless "i" in "oignon" and the oddball accents in "elevement".)

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
We want more school houses and less jails; more books and less arsenals;
more learning and less vice; more constant work and less crime; more
leisure and less greed; more justice and less revenge; in fact, more of
the opportunities to cultivate our better natures. --Samuel Gompers
